arguments.claim: Whether a firm is genuine or not is normally a question of fact

anchor.surface_text: It is equally true that whether a firm is genuine or not is normally a question of fact.

arguments.claim: The facts found by the Tribunal do not reasonably lead to the conclusion it has drawn and the conclusion is based on suspicion and surmise

anchor.surface_text: It is clear, however, that the grievance of the appellant is that the facts found by the Tribunal do not reasonably lead to the conclusion it has drawn and the conclusion is based on suspicion and surmise.

arguments.claim: On the above facts, the partnership claimed is not genuine and the deed is not intended to be acted upon; actual conduct inter se matters; firm not genuine and not registerable under section 26A

anchor.surface_text: On the above facts, we do not find it difficult to reach a conclusion that the partnership claimed on the basis of the deed dated November 16, 1949, is not genuine and that the deed is a document not intended to be acted upon. It may be so far as the outside world is concerned the three persons in question have held themselves out as partners, but that cannot by any means establish automatically the genuineness of the arrangement too. The actual conduct of the parties inter se is the essential point to bear in mind for this purpose. On the above facts, we hold that the firm is not genuine and accordingly not registerable under section 26-A.

arguments.court_reasoning: Inference unreasonable, no reference to conduct inter se, not justified by partnership law or experience

arguments.claim: Tribunal has not really referred to any conduct of the parties inter se which would indicate that the partnership was not genuine

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the relation between the parties which is not in dispute, the Tribunal has not really referred to any conduct of the parties inter se which would indicate that the partnership was not genuine.

arguments.claim: Underlying assumption of Tribunal that partnership of wife and brother-in-law must be suspect, and wife saving profits/brother-in-law not spending fully indicates bogus partnership

anchor.surface_text: The underlying assumption in the reasoning of the Tribunal seems to be that a partnership consisting of the wife and brother-in-law must be necessarily suspect and if the wife saves her profits and the brother- in -law does not spend his share of the profits fully, the inference must be that the partnership is a bogus partnership.

arguments.claim: Such an inference is unreasonable and not justified either by partnership law or common human experience

anchor.surface_text: On the materials placed before us, we consider that such an inference is unreasonable and not justified either by partnership law or common human experience.

arguments.claim: Books of accounts not held false; good reasons for partners not suggested absent; contributions accepted; brother-in-law managed business

anchor.surface_text: The books of partnership accounts were not held to be false nor was it suggested that there were no good reasons for taking the wife and brother-in-law as partners. It was accepted that both of them contributed their share of the capital, and it was not disputed that the brother-in-law managed the business, and at the relevant time lived with K. R. Setty.

arguments.claim: Rs. 50,000 contributed by Nagaratnamma was her stridhanam; Tribunal found she contributed as per deed

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent suggested that the sum of Rs. 50,000 which Nagaratnamma contributed might not be her stridhanam in law. It is enough to point out that no such finding was given by the Tribunal on the contrary, the Tribunal found that she contributed her share of the capital in the manner stated in the deed of partnership.
